speaker: Doctor
text: Can you tell me exactly when you first noticed the swelling and pain in your right ring finger, was it sudden or did it come on gradually?

speaker: Patient
text: It started pretty quickly, to be honest, I was playing football and my finger got caught in another guy's jersey and then he just yanked it away really hard, and after that I felt a sharp pain and noticed my finger was already swelling a bit.

speaker: Doctor
text: How would you describe the pain in your right ring finger - is it sharp and stabbing, dull and aching, or more of a burning sensation?

speaker: Patient
text: The pain is quite sharp and stabbing, it feels like a knife going into the skin, and it's been that way since the incident.

speaker: Doctor
text: Have you experienced any recent trauma or injury to your right hand or ring finger that could have triggered the swelling and pain, such as a cut, a blow, or a sudden twisting motion?

speaker: Patient
text: Yeah, like I mentioned, it happened during a football game when I got caught in the jersey, so that's pretty much it. I don't think there was anything else that could've caused it, it was just a pretty intense pull.

speaker: Doctor
text: Can you tell me if the pain and swelling in your right ring finger are constant, or do they seem to come and go, and are there any activities that seem to make them better or worse?

speaker: Patient
text: The pain and swelling seem to come and go, but the pain is more noticeable when I try to flex my finger or make a fist, especially when I've been active in football. When I'm resting, the swelling seems to subside a bit, but the pain still lingers. It's pretty uncomfortable, to be honest.

speaker: Doctor
text: Have you noticed any changes in the color or temperature of your right ring finger, such as redness, warmth, or coldness, especially when compared to your other fingers?

speaker: Patient
text: I did notice that my finger turned pretty pale and cool to the touch after the incident, almost like it was numb or something, and it's been that way ever since, but it's not really warm or red like it would be if I had a cut or something.

speaker: Doctor
text: Have you experienced any similar symptoms in your other fingers or hands, or is the swelling and pain limited to your right ring finger?

speaker: Patient
text: No, it's only the right ring finger, I've noticed that I can still move the other fingers normally and they don't feel any pain or swelling, it's just this one finger that's affected.

speaker: Doctor
text: Have you noticed any changes in your appetite or weight recently, or have you experienced any other symptoms such as fever, fatigue, or general feeling of being unwell?

speaker: Patient
text: No, nothing like that. I've been eating normal and feeling pretty good, just a bit more tired than usual after the football game, but I think that's just from the physical exertion.

speaker: Doctor
text: Have you noticed any lumps, bumps, or nodules on your right ring finger, or any changes in the skin such as thickening, thinning, or lesions?

speaker: Patient
text: I did notice a lump on my finger, it's pretty noticeable when I try to flex it. It's a bit hard to the touch and feels a bit tender to the touch, especially when I press on it gently.

speaker: Doctor
text: Have you noticed any difficulty moving your right ring finger, such as stiffness, limited range of motion, or weakness, especially when compared to your other fingers?

speaker: Patient
text: Yeah, I've noticed that I have a bit of stiffness when I try to flex my finger, especially when I've been active in football. It's hard to describe, but it feels like the joint just won't budge sometimes, and I have to force it to move. It's pretty annoying, to be honest.

speaker: Doctor
text: Can you tell me if you have any medical conditions, such as diabetes, arthritis, or gout, that could be contributing to the swelling and pain in your right ring finger?

speaker: Patient
text: I don't have any medical conditions that I know of, I'm pretty healthy and I don't take any medications that could be contributing to this. I do have a history of being active in sports, particularly football, and I've had a few sprains and strains in the past, but nothing that's ever caused this kind of swelling and pain.

speaker: Doctor
text: Have you ever had a condition that affects your joints or connective tissues, such as rheumatoid arthritis, lupus, or scleroderma, or a family history of such conditions?

speaker: Patient
text: I don't have any family history of those conditions, but I did have a bit of a problem with my ankle a few years ago when I was playing football, I think I might have torn a ligament or something, but it healed up on its own after a few weeks.

speaker: Doctor
text: Have you ever had any infections, such as paronychia or felon, in your right ring finger or any other part of your hand, and have you been treated with antibiotics or other medications for such infections?

speaker: Patient
text: No, I don't think so. I've never had an infection like that before. I do remember getting a bit of a cold a few weeks ago, but it was just a mild case and I didn't need any treatment for it.

speaker: Doctor
text: Can you tell me if you've recently traveled or been exposed to anyone who has been sick, and have you experienced any swollen lymph nodes or tenderness in your armpits or neck?

speaker: Patient
text: I actually went to a party with some friends last weekend, but I don't think I got exposed to anyone who was sick. I don't really remember anyone being sick there, and I didn't notice anything out of the ordinary.

speaker: Doctor
text: Have you noticed any numbness, tingling, or loss of sensation in your right ring finger, or any changes in your ability to feel sensations such as touch, pressure, or vibration?

speaker: Patient
text: No, I haven't really noticed any numbness or tingling in my right ring finger, but I did say it felt a bit cool to the touch after the incident, almost like it was numb or something.

speaker: Doctor
text: Can you show me exactly how you move your right ring finger, and can you bend it down toward your palm and then straighten it again, and does that cause any pain or discomfort?

speaker: Patient
text: Okay, so I'll try to move my finger like normal. *bends finger down toward palm* It's a bit stiff, but I can still do it. *straightens finger* It hurts a bit when I do it, but it's not too bad. When I try to flex it, like I mentioned before, it's more painful. *tries to flex finger, wincing slightly* Yeah, that feels like a sharp pain.

speaker: Doctor
text: Can you tell me if you've noticed any discharge, pus, or foul odor from the affected finger, or if you've had any recent nail biting, picking, or other habits that could be contributing to the infection?

speaker: Patient
text: No, I haven't noticed any discharge, pus, or foul odor from the affected finger, and I don't have any habits like nail biting or picking that could be contributing to an infection. I've actually been pretty careful with my fingernails lately, just making sure to keep them clean and trimmed.

speaker: Doctor
text: Can you tell me about your occupation and any activities you do regularly that involve using your right hand or ring finger, such as typing, writing, or manual labor?

speaker: Patient
text: I'm a student, so I don't really do any manual labor, but I'm pretty active in sports, especially football. I'm a wide receiver, so I spend a lot of time running with the ball and making cuts, which can be pretty demanding on my hands and fingers.

speaker: Doctor
text: Have you ever worn a ring on your right ring finger, and if so, have you noticed any changes in the fit of the ring or any irritation around the area where the ring sits?

speaker: Patient
text: I used to wear a ring on my right ring finger, but I took it off a few weeks ago. I didn't notice anything unusual about it, it just didn't feel comfortable anymore. I've been trying to break the habit of wearing it, but it's hard to forget the feeling of it sitting on my finger.

speaker: Doctor
text: Can you tell me more about your occupation, specifically what kind of manual labor or activities you do that involve using your right hand or ring finger, and how long you've been doing them?

speaker: Patient
text: I'm a wide receiver in football, so I spend a lot of time running with the ball and making cuts, which can be pretty demanding on my hands and fingers. I've been playing football since high school, so I've been doing it for about 5 years now.

speaker: Doctor
text: Can you tell me if you've experienced any similar symptoms in your other fingers or hands at any point in the past, even if they resolved on their own or with treatment?

speaker: Patient
text: No, nothing like that. I've had some sprains and strains in my other fingers and hands, but nothing that's ever caused swelling and pain like this.

speaker: Doctor
text: Have you ever experienced any symptoms such as morning stiffness in your fingers or hands, or stiffness after periods of rest or inactivity, and does the swelling in your right ring finger seem to be worse at any particular time of day?

speaker: Patient
text: Yeah, I've noticed some stiffness in my fingers and hands, especially in the mornings, but it's not too bad. The swelling seems to be worse after I've been active in football, like during practice or games, and it subsides a bit when I'm resting or not moving around as much.

speaker: Doctor
text: Can you rate the pain in your right ring finger on a scale of 1 to 10, with 1 being mild and 10 being severe, and does the pain seem to be getting better, worse, or staying the same over time?

speaker: Patient
text: I'd say the pain is an 8 out of 10, it's pretty intense. To be honest, it's been staying the same, but it's been getting a bit worse when I've been active in football, like during practice or games.

speaker: Doctor
text: Can you tell me if you've noticed any changes in your right ring finger's nail, such as thickening, brittleness, or discoloration, and have you experienced any pain or tenderness when pressing on the nail or surrounding skin?

speaker: Patient
text: I've noticed that my nail seems a bit thicker than usual, and it's been feeling a bit tender to the touch, especially around the base of the nail. When I press on it, it hurts a bit, but it's not too sharp or stabbing, more of a dull ache.

speaker: Doctor
text: Have you ever had any X-rays or imaging studies of your hands or fingers, and if so, what were the results, and would you be willing to have some X-rays taken today to help me further evaluate your condition?

speaker: Patient
text: I don't think I've ever had any X-rays or imaging studies of my hands or fingers, but I'm more than happy to have some taken today to help you figure out what's going on with my finger.

speaker: Doctor
text: Have you noticed any changes in the curvature or alignment of your right ring finger, such as bending or crookedness, especially when compared to your other fingers?

speaker: Patient
text: Yeah, I have noticed that it's a bit more bent than usual, especially when I try to flex it. It feels like the joint is out of place or something.

speaker: Doctor
text: Can you tell me if you have any allergies to medications, or have you had any adverse reactions to antibiotics or pain medications in the past?

speaker: Patient
text: No, I don't think I've had any allergies to medications or had any adverse reactions to antibiotics or pain medications in the past. I've taken some pain relievers for sprains and strains before, but that was a few years ago and I didn't have any issues.

speaker: Doctor
text: Can you tell me if you've noticed any changes in the sensation or feeling of your right ring finger when you press on the affected area or surrounding skin, and do you experience any sharp pains or electric shock-like sensations when doing so?

speaker: Patient
text: Yeah, when I press on the affected area, it feels a bit numb, but then I get a sharp pain, like a shock or a jolt, it's hard to describe, but it's definitely there.

speaker: Doctor
text: Can you tell me if you've experienced any symptoms such as swelling, redness, or warmth in any of your other joints, such as your knees, elbows, or wrists, in addition to your right ring finger?

speaker: Patient
text: No, I haven't experienced any symptoms like that in my other joints, but I did notice that my knee is a bit sore after playing football, it's probably just from the physical exertion and impact of running with the ball.

speaker: Doctor
text: Can you tell me more about your typical daily activities and how you think they may be contributing to the swelling and pain in your right ring finger, and are there any specific actions or movements that you've noticed trigger the pain or discomfort?

speaker: Patient
text: I'd say my daily activities are pretty active, especially with football and school. I'm always running around, playing sports, and studying, which can be pretty physically demanding. I think the swelling and pain might be related to the impact and friction on my finger when I'm moving around and playing sports, especially when I try to flex it or make a fist.

speaker: Doctor
text: Can you tell me if you've ever experienced any symptoms such as locking or catching in your right ring finger, where it feels like the finger gets stuck in a bent position and then suddenly releases, and does this happen frequently or only occasionally?

speaker: Patient
text: Yeah, I've noticed that my finger does get stuck in a bent position, like it's locked, and then it suddenly releases, it feels a bit like a catch or a snap, it's pretty uncomfortable, and it happens pretty frequently, especially when I'm trying to flex it or make a fist.

speaker: Doctor
text: Can you tell me if you've noticed any changes in your right ring finger's range of motion, such as difficulty bending or straightening the finger, and does the pain or stiffness seem to be worse with certain movements or activities?

speaker: Patient
text: Yeah, I've noticed that my finger has less range of motion than usual, especially when I try to flex it or make a fist. The pain seems to be worse when I'm bending or straightening my finger, especially when I've been active in football.

speaker: Doctor
text: Can you tell me if you've experienced any recent changes in your overall health, such as stress, anxiety, or depression, that could be contributing to the swelling and pain in your right ring finger?

speaker: Patient
text: I've been pretty stressed out lately with school and football, but I don't think that's directly related to the swelling and pain in my finger. I mean, I've been dealing with that for a few days now, and it's been pretty consistent, so I don't think it's a result of stress or anxiety.

speaker: Doctor
text: Can you tell me if you've ever experienced any symptoms such as gout or pseudogout in your right ring finger, or have you had a family history of these conditions, and do you consume a diet that is high in purines, such as organ meats, seafood, or beer?

speaker: Patient
text: I don't think I've ever had anything like that before, but I do like beer and I'm not sure if it's a big deal or not.

speaker: Doctor
text: Can you tell me more about your diet and if you consume a lot of sugary drinks or foods that are high in salt, and have you noticed any correlation between your diet and the swelling or pain in your right ring finger?

speaker: Patient
text: To be honest, I try to eat a pretty balanced diet, I mean, I eat a lot of fruits and vegetables, whole grains, and lean proteins. I do enjoy a few beers on the weekends, but I don't think that's too much. I also try to stay hydrated by drinking plenty of water. I haven't really noticed any correlation between my diet and the swelling or pain in my finger, but I do think the beer might be a bit of a contributing factor, especially since it happened after I drank a few beers on Saturday night.

speaker: Doctor
text: Can you tell me if you've ever experienced any symptoms such as carpal tunnel syndrome or tendinitis in your wrists or hands, and have you noticed any numbness or tingling in your fingers or hands, especially after activities that involve repetitive motions?

speaker: Patient
text: I've had some issues with wrist sprains in the past, but I don't think it's directly related to the swelling and pain in my finger. I do remember that my wrist tends to get a bit stiff and sore after long practice sessions, but it usually goes away on its own after a few days.

speaker: Doctor
text: Have you ever experienced any symptoms such as Raynaud's phenomenon, where your fingers turn white or blue in response to cold temperatures or stress, and have you noticed any changes in the color of your right ring finger in response to changes in temperature?

speaker: Patient
text: Yeah, I've noticed that my finger does turn a bit pale when I'm cold, but it's not like my fingers turn white or anything, it's more of a cool color.

speaker: Doctor
text: Can you tell me if you've noticed any changes in your right ring finger's nail, such as thickening, brittleness, or discoloration, and have you experienced any pain or tenderness when pressing on the nail or surrounding skin, and also, have you had any fungal infections in the past, such as onychomycosis?

speaker: Patient
text: Yeah, my nail does seem a bit thicker than usual, and it's been feeling a bit tender to the touch, especially around the base of the nail. When I press on it, it hurts a bit, but it's not too sharp or stabbing, more of a dull ache. And, to be honest, I've had a bit of a fungal infection in the past, onychomycosis, it was on my big toe, but it healed up on its own after a few weeks.

speaker: Doctor
text: Have you ever had a condition that affects your nails, such as psoriasis or eczema, or have you noticed any changes in the skin around your right ring finger, such as scaling, cracking, or lesions?

speaker: Patient
text: Yeah, I did have a fungal infection on my big toe a few years ago, but it healed up on its own. I've also had some issues with eczema on my hands and feet in the past, but it's been pretty under control lately. I don't really notice any changes in the skin around my right ring finger, but I do have a bit of redness and tenderness around the area where the swelling is.

speaker: Doctor
text: Can you tell me if you've ever had any infections, such as cellulitis or abscesses, in your right ring finger or any other part of your hand, and have you been treated with antibiotics or other medications for such infections?

speaker: Patient
text: No, I don't think I've ever had any infections like that before. I did get a bit of a cold a few weeks ago, but it was just a mild case and I didn't need any treatment for it.

speaker: Doctor
text: Can you tell me if you've noticed any changes in the skin around your right ring finger, such as redness, swelling, or warmth, especially when you press on the affected area or surrounding skin?

speaker: Patient
text: Yeah, I have noticed that the skin around my right ring finger is a bit red and swollen, especially when I press on the affected area. It's pretty tender to the touch, and when I press on it gently, I can feel a bit of warmth, but it's not like it's burning or anything.

speaker: Doctor
text: Can you tell me if you've experienced any pain or discomfort when I press on the affected area or surrounding skin of your right ring finger, and are there any specific areas that seem to be more tender than others?

speaker: Patient
text: Yeah, when I press on the affected area, it hurts a bit, but it's not too sharp or stabbing, more of a dull ache. The pain is most noticeable when I press on the area around the joint, like just above the bend of the finger, it's really tender to the touch.

speaker: Doctor
text: Can you tell me if you've noticed any changes in the swelling or pain in your right ring finger after resting or elevating your hand, and does the swelling seem to be worse at the base of the finger, near the joint, or more towards the tip?

speaker: Patient
text: Yeah, when I rest my hand, the swelling seems to subside a bit, but the pain still lingers. And yeah, it's more noticeable near the joint, near the bend of the finger, it feels like the pain is more concentrated there.

speaker: Doctor
text: Can you tell me if the pain in your right ring finger is relieved at all when you soak your hand in warm water or apply a warm compress, and have you tried any over-the-counter pain medications, such as acetaminophen or ibuprofen, to help manage the pain?

speaker: Patient
text: Actually, soaking my hand in warm water does help a bit, it reduces the swelling, but the pain still lingers. As for pain medications, I've tried acetaminophen a few times, but it doesn't seem to make a huge difference, I mean, it's still pretty painful.

speaker: Doctor
text: Can you show me the exact area of your right ring finger where you experience the most pain and tenderness, and I'll take a closer look?

speaker: Patient
text: Okay, I'll show you. *points to the affected area* It's right here, just above the bend of the finger, where the joint is. That's where the pain and tenderness are most noticeable.

speaker: Doctor
text: Can you tell me if you've noticed any changes in the swelling or pain in your right ring finger after applying ice or cold compresses, and have you tried any topical creams or ointments to help reduce the swelling or pain?

speaker: Patient
text: Yeah, I did try applying ice to the affected area a few times, and it did help reduce the swelling a bit, but the pain still lingered. As for topical creams or ointments, I've tried some over-the-counter creams for sprains and strains, but I don't think they've made a huge difference, I mean, the pain is still pretty intense.

speaker: Doctor
text: Can you tell me if you've noticed any changes in your right ring finger's sensitivity to pressure or touch, and does the pain seem to be more severe when you apply pressure to the affected area or surrounding skin?

speaker: Patient
text: Yeah, the pain seems to be more severe when I apply pressure to the affected area or surrounding skin, it feels like it's more concentrated there. And yeah, I have noticed that my finger is a bit more sensitive to pressure or touch than usual, especially when I press on the area around the joint.

speaker: Doctor
text: Can you tell me if you've ever experienced any symptoms such as Dupuytren's contracture, where a thickening of the tissue in the palm of the hand causes the fingers to curl or bend, and have you noticed any thickening or nodules in the palm of your hand near your right ring finger?

speaker: Patient
text: I don't think I've ever heard of that condition before, but now that you mention it, I did notice that my finger feels a bit stiff and like it's curling in on itself, especially when I try to flex it. And yeah, I did notice a small lump on my finger, it's pretty noticeable when I try to flex it, and it's a bit hard to the touch.

speaker: Doctor
text: Can you tell me if you've noticed any changes in the way your right ring finger looks or feels when you compare it to your other fingers, and are there any specific differences that stand out to you, such as size, color, or texture?

speaker: Patient
text: Yeah, I did notice that my right ring finger looks a bit different, it's a bit smaller than my other fingers, and it's a bit more bent than usual, especially when I try to flex it. It's like the joint is out of place or something, and it feels a bit stiff and stiff, like it's not moving as smoothly as the other fingers.

speaker: Doctor
text: Can you tell me if you've ever experienced any similar symptoms in your feet or toes, such as swelling, pain, or stiffness, and do you have a family history of any conditions that affect the hands or feet, such as arthritis or gout?

speaker: Patient
text: No, I don't think so. I've never had any issues with my feet or toes, but I do have a family history of arthritis, my mom and dad both have it, and my grandma had some issues with her hands too.

speaker: Doctor
text: REQUEST TEST: X-Ray of right hand, specifically the ring finger.

DIAGNOSIS_READY_Answer: Rupture of the flexor digitorum profundus tendon at its point of insertion
